qas.question: How are the three component used to determine sexual orientation?

answers.text: all three are used independently and provide different conclusions regarding sexual orientation

qas.question: When did Savin WIlliams talk about the issues with these components?
What issues to Savin address during this talk?

answers.text: basing findings regarding sexual orientation on a single component, researchers may not actually capture the intended population

qas.question: Why does basing sexual orientation on one component cause problems?

answers.text: Because of the limited populations that each component captures

qas.question: How should consumers of the research approach these findings?

answers.text: should be cautious in generalizing these findings.

context: As there is no research indicating which of the three components is essential in defining sexual orientation, <a0_0>all three are used independently and provide different conclusions regarding sexual orientation<a0_0/>. Savin Williams <a1_0>(2006)<a1_0/> discusses this issue and notes that by <a2_0>basing findings regarding sexual orientation on a single component, researchers may not actually capture the intended population<a2_0/>. For example, if homosexual is defined by same sex behavior, gay virgins are omitted, heterosexuals engaging in same sex behavior for other reasons than preferred sexual arousal are miscounted, and those with same sex attraction who only have opposite-sex relations are excluded. <a3_0>Because of the limited populations that each component captures<a3_0/>, consumers of research <a4_0>should be cautious in generalizing these findings.
